theme.title: The staff
theme.para: In the Western musical notation system music is written on specially printed paper called 'manuscript paper'.

The manuscript paper is organized as sets of horizontal lines, named 'staves' (Note: Each group of horizontal lines is called a 'staff', with 'staves' as the plural. Note that althoug in American English 'staff' is the right term, in British English the word 'staff' is old-fashioned and rarely used; they use the word 'stave' instead). A staff is a set of five horizontal lines, numbered from bottom to top; the bottom line is the first line and the top line is the fifth line:

score.music: (Metrica 2 4)(n a4 c g+)(n a4 c l g-)(n a4 c g+)(n a4 s)(n a4 s g-)(Barra Doble))

theme.para: The four spaces between the staff lines, are important and are also numbered from bottom to top:

score.music: (Metrica 2 4)(n a4 c g+)(n a4 c l g-)(n a4 c g+)(n a4 s)(n a4 s g-)(Barra Doble))

theme.para: The musical symbols are placed on the staff. The symbols for notes are placed either on a line or on a space and the musical pitch (low or high) represented by the symbol is determined by the position of the note on the staff. Notes on the higher lines/spaces have higer pitch than those on the lower ones. Lesson to the next scale:

score.music: (Metrica 2 4)(n a4 c g+)(n a4 c l g-)(n a4 c g+)(n a4 s)(n a4 s g-)(Barra Doble))

theme.para: Music on the staff is read from left to right.
